newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Midwest power up about $20/MWh from week-ago.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Midwest power up about $20/MWh from week-ago.

text.p: Wholesale spot electricity prices for the U.S. Midwest were steady to higher Thursday, gaining about $20 on week-ago levels, but the market was beginning to show some stability, sources said.
Temperatures throughout most of the Midwest are expected to be much below normal Friday but then moderate slightly for the weekend.
However, another cold front is expected to arrive early next week, weighing temperatures down about 15-25 degrees Fahrenheit below-normal.

In the Mid-Continent Area Power Pool (MAPP), peak non-firm power prices for Friday delivery were in the $40.00-42.00 per megawatt hour (MWh) range, as compared with Wednesday's $41.00-43.00 trading range.
Off-peak non-firm MAPP power deals were assessed at $16.00-17.00.
In the Mid-American Interpool Network (MAIN), peak, non-firm power prices for Friday delivery were about $1 higher in the $40.00-41.00 range.
Next-week peak prices in MAIN were talked significantly lower in the $27.50-28.50 range.
MAIN off peak power was notionally assessed in the $15.00-16.00 range.

Peak, non-firm electricity prices in the East Central Area Reliability Coordination Agreement (ECAR) for Friday were in the $40.00-42.00 range, as compared with Wednesday's $36.00-37.00 trading range. Some deals were reported done as high as $45.00.
Peak prices for next week in ECAR were talked around $28.00.
January/February ECAR prices were steady in the $25.50-26.00 range, while March business was still talked in the $21.40-22.00 area.
Off-peak, non-firm next-day ECAR power was notionally talked up at least a $1 at $16.00.
In the Southwest Power Pool (SPP), peak non-firm power for Friday delivery was quoted mostly around $42 per MWh, up about $2 from Wednesday's trading range.
January/February peak prices in SPP were talked up about 20 cents to the $27.80-29.10 range, while March prices were around $23.75-24.25 range, traders said.
Off-peak prices throughout SPP were notionally around $17.00.
Kansas City Power and Light Co's 670 megawatt (MW) Iatan coal-fired unit, shut early Tuesday, was set to return to service around 1200 CST Thursday, the company said.
Also, Omaha Public Service's 585 MW coal-fired unit in Nebraska City, Neb., is expected to resume operating early Friday.

Contributing to the stronger electricity prices were the still higher natural gas prices. In the Midcontinent, gas for Friday delivery amid pipeline freeze-offs traded anywhere from $4.60 to about $4.80, with the bulk of the deals done in the high-$4.60s.
